projectDesc.p: "Wandering lost, it was already night" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Herkneþ to me boþe eld & ȝing,
app.rdg: Listen to me, both old and young,

app.lem: For Maries loue þat swete þing,
app.rdg: For the love of Mary, that precious woman,

app.lem: Al hou a wer bigan
app.rdg: About how a war began

app.lem: Bitvene a trewe Cristen king
app.rdg: Between a true, Christian king

app.lem: & an heþen heye lording,
app.rdg: And a pagan high lord,

app.lem: Of Dames þe soudan.
app.rdg: The sultan of Damascus.

app.lem: Þe king of Tars hadde a wiue,
app.rdg: The King of Tars had [married] a wife,

app.lem: Feirer miȝt non ben oliue
app.rdg: Of whom any man could say

app.lem: Þat ani wiȝt telle can.
app.rdg: A lovelier woman had never lived.

app.lem: A douhter þai hadde hem bitven,
app.rdg: Between them they bore a daughter,

app.lem: Non feirer woman miȝt ben,
app.rdg: Than whom no woman might be lovelier,

app.lem: As white as feþer of swan.
app.rdg: As white as the feather of a swan.

app.lem: Þe meiden was schast & bliþe of chere,
app.rdg: The maiden was chaste and happy in appearance,

app.lem: Wiþ rode red so blosme on brere,
app.rdg: With cheeks as red as a flower on a bush,

app.lem: & eyȝen stepe & gray;
app.rdg: And [with] bright grey eyes;

app.lem: Wiþ lowe scholders & white swere,
app.rdg: With low shoulders and a white neck,

app.lem: Hir forto sen was gret preier
app.rdg: To court her was the wish

app.lem: Of princes proud in play.
app.rdg: Of proud and youthful princes.

app.lem: Þe los of hir gan spring wide
app.rdg: The talk of her did spread about

app.lem: In oþer londes bi ich a side;
app.rdg: In other countries on every side;

app.lem: So þe soudan herd it say.
app.rdg: So the sultan heard it spoken.

app.lem: Him þouȝt his hert it brast o fiue
app.rdg: He thought his heart would break in five pieces

app.lem: Bot ȝif he miȝt haue hir to wiue
app.rdg: Unless he could have her as his wife,

app.lem: Þat was so feir a may.
app.rdg: [She] Who was so lovely a maiden.

app.lem: His messangers he gan calle,
app.rdg: He did summon all his messengers,

app.lem: & bad hem wiȝtly wenden alle
app.rdg: And ordered them all to go quickly

app.lem: To hir fader, þe king;
app.rdg: To her father, the king;

app.lem: & seyd he wald, houso it bifalle,
app.rdg: He said whatever it takes, he would

app.lem: His douhter cloþe in riche palle,
app.rdg: Dress his daughter in royal robes

app.lem: & spouse hir wiþ his ring.
app.rdg: And wed her with his ring.

app.lem: & ȝif he nold, wiþouten feyl,
app.rdg: If he would not, then without fail,

app.lem: He wald hir win in batayl
app.rdg: He would win her in battle

app.lem: Wiþ mani an heye lording.
app.rdg: With many a high lord.

app.lem: Þe messangers forþ þai went
app.rdg: The messengers set out

app.lem: To don þe soudans comandment
app.rdg: To obey the sultan’s command

app.lem: Wiþouten ani duelling.
app.rdg: Without any delay.

app.lem: Þan þe king of Tars þis vnderstode,
app.rdg: Once the King of Tars learned this,

app.lem: Almest for wretþe he wex ner wode,
app.rdg: He almost nearly went mad out of anger

app.lem: & seyd þus in sawe,
app.rdg: And by his words said this:

app.lem: ‘Bi him þat dyed on þe rode,
app.rdg: “By He who died on the cross,

app.lem: Ich wald arst spille min hert-blode
app.rdg: I would sooner shed my heart’s blood

app.lem: In bateyl to ben yslawe.
app.rdg: And be killed in battle.

app.lem: Y nold hir ȝiue a Sarazin
app.rdg: I will never give her to a Muslim

app.lem: For alle þe lond þat is mine;
app.rdg: For all the land I rule,

app.lem: Þe deuel him arst todrawe.
app.rdg: Let the devil sooner hang him!

app.lem: Bot sche wil wiþ hir gode wille
app.rdg: Unless, with her consent, she will

app.lem: Be wedded to him hirselue to spille;
app.rdg: Be married to him and spoil herself.

app.lem: Hir þouȝtes nouȝt y no knawe,
app.rdg: I ought not to know her thoughts,

app.lem: Ac y schal wite ar þan ȝe pas.’
app.rdg: “But I shall learn them before anything happens.”

app.lem: His douhter anon was brouȝt in plas,
app.rdg: His daughter was brought before him at once,

app.lem: & he axed hir biliue,
app.rdg: And he asked her immediately:

app.lem: ‘Douhter, þe soudan of Damas
app.rdg: “Daughter, the sultan of Damascus

app.lem: ȝernes forto se þi fas,
app.rdg: Longs to see your face

app.lem: & wald þe haue to wiue.
app.rdg: And would take you as his wife.

app.lem: Waldestow, douhter, for tresour,
app.rdg: Daughter, would you for his riches

app.lem: Forsake Ihesus our saueour,
app.rdg: Turn back on Jesus, our saviour,

app.lem: Þat suffred woundes fiue?’
app.rdg: Who suffered five wounds?”

app.lem: Þe maiden answerd wiþ mild mod
app.rdg: The maiden answered with mild manner

app.lem: Biforn hir fader þer sche stode,
app.rdg: From where she stood before her father:

app.lem: ‘Nay lord, so mot y þriue.
app.rdg: “Never, lord, so let me live!

app.lem: Ihesu, mi Lord in trinite,
app.rdg: “Jesus, my Lord in trinity,

app.lem: Lat me neuer þat day yse
app.rdg: Let me never see the day

app.lem: A tirant forto take.
app.rdg: I marry a tyrant.

app.lem: O God & persones þre
app.rdg: One [Almighty] God, [who is in] three persons,

app.lem: For Marie loue, þi moder fre,
app.rdg: For the love of Mary, Your queenly mother,

app.lem: ȝif him arst tene & wrake.’
app.rdg: Sooner give him pain and retribution.”

app.lem: Þe king seyd ‘douhter, be stille.
app.rdg: The king said: “Daughter, be at ease.

app.lem: Þou schalt neuer be wedded him tille,
app.rdg: You shall never be married to him,

app.lem: For no bost he can make.
app.rdg: No matter what threats he makes.

app.lem: Y schal him sende word oȝein
app.rdg: I shall send him reply

app.lem: Þat alle his þouȝtes ben in vein,
app.rdg: That all his advances are in vain,

app.lem: For þou hast him forsake.’
app.rdg: Because you have rejected him.”

app.lem: Riȝt be þe self messangers
app.rdg: By the same messengers

app.lem: Þat com fro þe soudan fers,
app.rdg: That came from the wicked sultan,

app.lem: Þis wordes he him sent,
app.rdg: [The king] sent him back these words:

app.lem: Þat sche leued nouȝt on his maners;
app.rdg: That she did not believe in his principles,

app.lem: Sche nold nouȝt leten hir preiers
app.rdg: [And] She would never cease her prayers

app.lem: To God omnipotent.
app.rdg: To God omnipotent.

app.lem: He bad him tak anoþer thouȝt,
app.rdg: He suggested [to the sultan] that he reconsider,

app.lem: For of his douhter no tit him nouȝt
app.rdg: Because he was not entitled to his daughter

app.lem: For tresore no for rent.
app.rdg: Neither for his riches nor for purchase.

app.lem: Þe messangers herd him þus seyn,
app.rdg: So the messengers heard him say,

app.lem: Wiþ þat word þai turned oȝain
app.rdg: [And] With that word they turned back

app.lem: & to þe soudan þai went.
app.rdg: And returned to the sultan.

app.lem: As þe soudan sat at his des,
app.rdg: They came into the hall (87)

app.lem: Yserued of þe first mes,
app.rdg: As the sultan sat upon his throne, (85)

app.lem: Þai com into þe halle.
app.rdg: Having eaten the morning meal. (86)

app.lem: Bifor þo princes prout in pres
app.rdg: Before the battle-hardened princes

app.lem: Her tale to telle wiþouten les
app.rdg: They fell down upon their knees (90)

app.lem: On knes þai gun doun falle.
app.rdg: To tell their tale, without any deceit. (89)

app.lem: Þai seyd ‘sir, þe king of Tars
app.rdg: They said: “Sire, the King of Tars

app.lem: Of wicked wordes is nouȝt scars;
app.rdg: Is not wanting of wicked words.

app.lem: Heþen hounde he gan þe calle,
app.rdg: ‘Pagan hound’ he did call you,

app.lem: & ar he ȝiue his douhter þe t[i]lle
app.rdg: And [said that] before he his gives his daughter up to you

app.lem: Þine hert-blod he will sp[i]lle,
app.rdg: He will shed your heart’s blood,

app.lem: & þine barouns alle.’
app.rdg: And [the blood] of all your barons.”

app.lem: When þe soudan þis wordes herd,
app.rdg: When the sultan heard these words,

app.lem: Also a wilde bore he ferd;
app.rdg: He acted like a wild boar.

app.lem: His robe he rent adoun,
app.rdg: He tore apart his robes,

app.lem: His here he rent of heued & berd.
app.rdg: [And] He pulled the hair from his head and beard.

app.lem: He schuld venge him wiþ his swerd,
app.rdg: He swore on the saint [prophet] Muhammad (102)

app.lem: He swore bi seyn Mahoun.
app.rdg: That he should avenge himself with his sword. (101)

app.lem: Þe table so heteliche he smot
app.rdg: He struck the table so hatefully

app.lem: It fel into þe flore fot-hot,
app.rdg: That it crashed down to the floor,

app.lem: & [he] loked as a lyoun.
app.rdg: And [he] looked like a lion.

app.lem: Al þat he rauȝt he smot doun riȝt:
app.rdg: Everything that he touched, he struck down:

app.lem: Seriaunt, squier, clerk & kniȝt,
app.rdg: Sergeant, squire, clerk, and knight,

app.lem: Boþe erl & baroun.
app.rdg: Both earl and baron.

app.lem: Al þus þe soudan ferd, y pliȝt,
app.rdg: Indeed, the sultan acted thusly

app.lem: Al þat day & alle þat niȝt;
app.rdg: All the day and all the night;

app.lem: Noman miȝt him schast.
app.rdg: Not a man could handle him.

app.lem: Amorwe, when it was liȝt,
app.rdg: In the morning, when it was light,

app.lem: His messangers he sent ful riȝt
app.rdg: Right away he sent his messengers

app.lem: For his barouns wel fast
app.rdg: Posthaste to his barons

app.lem: Þat þai com to his parlement
app.rdg: So that they meet in his war-room

app.lem: For to heren his iugement,
app.rdg: To hear his plan,

app.lem: Boþe lest & mast.
app.rdg: From both the least to the greatest.

app.lem: When þe parlement was pleyner,
app.rdg: When the council of war was assembled

app.lem: Þo bispac þe soudan fer,
app.rdg: The mighty sultan spoke,

app.lem: & seyd to hem in hast:
app.rdg: And said to them in haste:

app.lem: ‘Lordinges’ he seyd ‘what to red?’
app.rdg: “Lords,” he said, “give me your advice.

app.lem: Me haþ ben don a gret misdede
app.rdg: I have been terribly insulted

app.lem: Of Tars, þe Cristen king
app.rdg: By the Christian King of Tars!

app.lem: Y bede him boþe lond & lede
app.rdg: I offered to him both [my] land and [my] subjects

app.lem: For his douhter, worþliche in wede,
app.rdg: For his daughter, desirable in marriage,

app.lem: To han wed hir wiþ ring.
app.rdg: To have married her with my ring.

app.lem: & he me sent word ogain
app.rdg: He has sent me reply

app.lem: In bateyl y schuld arst be sleyn
app.rdg: That I should sooner be slain in battle

app.lem: & mani an heye lording.
app.rdg: And [with] many a high lord.

app.lem: & certes he schal be forsworn -
app.rdg: Indeed, he shall be destroyed -

app.lem: Wroþerhele þan was he born -
app.rdg: Rather he was born into misfortune -

app.lem: Bot y þerto it bring.
app.rdg: Than to [the destruction] I will bring.

app.lem: & þerfore ich haue after ȝou sent,
app.rdg: “That is why I have sent for you

app.lem: & asembled here þis parlement,
app.rdg: And here assembled this council of war,

app.lem: To wite ȝour conseyle.’
app.rdg: To seek your advice.”

app.lem: & alle þai seyd wiþ gode entent
app.rdg: They all said, in good faith,

app.lem: Þai were at his comandment,
app.rdg: [That] they awaited his command,

app.lem: Certeyn, wiþouten feile.
app.rdg: Surely, and without fail:

app.lem: Riȝt bi þat day a fourtenniȝt
app.rdg: Within fourteen days of that meeting

app.lem: Þai schul ben alle redi diȝt
app.rdg: They should all be made ready

app.lem: Wiþ helme [&] hauberk of meile.
app.rdg: With helms [and] coats of mail.

app.lem: & whan þai were so at his hest,
app.rdg: When they were thus at his command,

app.lem: Þe soudan made a riche fest
app.rdg: The sultan prepared a sumptuous feast

app.lem: For loue of his bateyle.
app.rdg: To celebrate the campaign.

app.lem: Þe soudan gaderd a rout vnride
app.rdg: The sultan mustered up a massive force

app.lem: Of Sarraȝins of michel pride
app.rdg: Of Muslims great in pride

app.lem: Opon þe king to (to) wende.
app.rdg: To sally against the king.

app.lem: Þe king of Tars herd sey þat tide,
app.rdg: The King of Tars heard rumors of war;

app.lem: He gadred his ost bi ich a side,
app.rdg: He massed his army on every side,

app.lem: Al þat he miȝt ofsende.
app.rdg: All whom he could summon.

app.lem: Þan bigan wretþe to wake,
app.rdg: Then they began to grow angry,

app.lem: For þat mariage miȝt nouȝt take
app.rdg: So that marriage might not take [away]

app.lem: Of þat maiden hende.
app.rdg: That gentle maiden.

app.lem: Of bateyl þai gun sett a day,
app.rdg: They did prepare a day for the battle,

app.lem: Of seynt Eline, þe þridde in May.
app.rdg: [The day] of Saint Helen, the third of May.

app.lem: No lenger no wald þai lende.
app.rdg: They would permit no delay.

app.lem: Þe soudan com wiþ his pouwer,
app.rdg: The sultan came with his forces

app.lem: Wiþ briȝt armour & brod baner
app.rdg: To fight upon the field, (172)

app.lem: Into þe feld to fiȝt,
app.rdg: With sixty-thousand fearsome Muslims (173)

app.lem: Wiþ sexti þousend Sarraȝins fer,
app.rdg: [Bearing] bright armor and lofty banners, (171)

app.lem: Þat alle þe feldes fer & ner
app.rdg: So that all the fields near and far

app.lem: Wiþ helmes lemed liȝt.
app.rdg: Gleamed with the light from their helms.

app.lem: Þe king of Tars com wiþ his ost,
app.rdg: The King of Tars came with his army,

app.lem: Wiþ gret pride & michel bost,
app.rdg: With great pride and haughty boast,

app.lem: Wiþ mani an hardi kniȝt.
app.rdg: [And] with many a manly knight.

app.lem: & aiþer ost gan oþer aseyle;
app.rdg: Either army did close with the other;

app.lem: Þer miȝt men se a strong bateyle
app.rdg: There men might see a battle

app.lem: Þat grimli was of siȝt.
app.rdg: Which was gruesome to look upon.

app.lem: Þer hewe houndes on Cristenmen
app.rdg: There the [pagan] hounds cut down [with their swords] Christian men

app.lem: & feld hem doun bi niȝen & ten.
app.rdg: And cut them down [thinned their ranks] by nines and tens.

app.lem: So wilde þai were & wode
app.rdg: So frenzied and angry were they

app.lem: Þat men miȝt sen alle þe fen
app.rdg: That men might see [lying] upon the ground

app.lem: Of Cristen boþe fremd & ken;
app.rdg: Christian men both stranger and family;

app.lem: Þe valays ren on blod.
app.rdg: The valleys ran wet with [their] blood.

app.lem: Þe soudan & his folk þat stounde
app.rdg: That moment, the sultan and his men

app.lem: Hewe adoun wiþ grimli wounde
app.rdg: Cut down [repulsed] with gruesome wounds

app.lem: Mani a frely fode.
app.rdg: Many a valiant assault.

app.lem: Allas, to wele sped Mahoun.
app.rdg: Alas! Muhammad sped to victory.

app.lem: Þe Cristenmen ȝede al adoun;
app.rdg: The Christian men suffered such a defeat,

app.lem: Was nouȝt þat hem wiþstode.
app.rdg: [That] there was no one who withstood [the enemy].

app.lem: Þe king of Tars seye þat siȝt,
app.rdg: The King of Tars saw the sight;

app.lem: For wretþe he was neye wode, apliȝt.
app.rdg: Indeed, he had nearly gone mad with anger.

app.lem: He hent in hond a spere,
app.rdg: He hefted a spear in his hand,

app.lem: & to þe soudan he rode ful riȝt,
app.rdg: And he rode hard upon the sultan.

app.lem: Wiþ a stroke o[f] michel miȝt
app.rdg: He took him to the ground (186)

app.lem: To grounde he gan him bere.
app.rdg: With a stroke of mighty power (185).

app.lem: Þer he hadde þe soudan slawe,
app.rdg: There he would have killed the sultan,

app.lem: Ac ten þousend of heþen lawe
app.rdg: But ten-thousand of the pagan faith

app.lem: Saued him in þat were.
app.rdg: Saved him from that danger.

app.lem: Þai sett him on a ful gode stede
app.rdg: They set him on a freshened horse

app.lem: Þat was so gode at eueri nede
app.rdg: Which was so responsive to every command

app.lem: Þat noman miȝt him dere.
app.rdg: hat no man could contest him.

app.lem: & when he was opon his stede,
app.rdg: When [the sultan] sat upon his horse,

app.lem: Him þouȝt he brend so spark on glede
app.rdg: They imagined he burned like an ember on a coal

app.lem: For ire & for envie.
app.rdg: Out of anger and of spite.

app.lem: He fauȝt so he wald wede;
app.rdg: He fought as if he was mad;

app.lem: Alle þat he hit he maked blede.
app.rdg: All that he struck, he made it bleed.

app.lem: ‘Help, Mahoun’ he gan crie.
app.rdg: “Help, Muhammad!” he did shout.

app.lem: Mani helme þer was ofweued,
app.rdg: There were many helms struck off,

app.lem: & mani bacinet tocleued,
app.rdg: Many visors [were] sliced in half,

app.lem: & sadles fel emtye.
app.rdg: And saddles [were] fallen empty.

app.lem: Mani swerd & mani scheld
app.rdg: Many swords and many shields

app.lem: & mani kniȝt lay in þe feld
app.rdg: And many knights lay [dead] on the field

app.lem: Of Cristen compeynie.
app.rdg: Among the Christian army.

app.lem: Þe king of Tars seye him so ride;
app.rdg: The King of Tars saw him riding thusly;

app.lem: He fleye, & durst nouȝt abide,
app.rdg: He fled, and dared not linger,

app.lem: Homward to his cite.
app.rdg: Back home to his city.

app.lem: Þe Sarraȝins folwed in þat tide,
app.rdg: The Muslims followed in that instance

app.lem: & slouȝ adoun bi ich a side
app.rdg: And struck down on every side

app.lem: Þat Cristen folk so fre.
app.rdg: The noble, Christian people.

app.lem: Þritti þousend þer were yslawe
app.rdg: There were slain thirty-thousand

app.lem: Of kniȝtes of Cristen lawe,
app.rdg: Knights of the Christian faith,

app.lem: & þat was gret pite.
app.rdg: And such a shame it was!

app.lem: Amorwe, for her boþer sake,
app.rdg: In the morning, for both of their benefit,

app.lem: Trewes þai gun bitven hem take,
app.rdg: They did make a truce between them,

app.lem: A moneþ & dayes þre.
app.rdg: For one month and three days [in duration].

app.lem: On a day þe king sat in his halle,
app.rdg: One day, the king sat in his hall

app.lem: & made grete diol wiþalle,
app.rdg: And became utterly lost in sorrow,

app.lem: For his folk were forlore.
app.rdg: For his people were hopeless.

app.lem: His douhter com clad in palle,
app.rdg: His daughter came wearing robes,

app.lem: Adoun on knes sche gan to falle,
app.rdg: And she did fall on her knees,

app.lem: & seyd wiþ sikeing sore,
app.rdg: And said with deep sighing:

app.lem: ‘Sir, lete me be þe soudans wiif,
app.rdg: “Sire, let me be the sultan’s wife,

app.lem: & rere namore cuntek no striif
app.rdg: And cause neither calamity nor strife

app.lem: As haþ ben here bifore.
app.rdg: As there has been here since.

app.lem: For me haþ mani man ben schent,
app.rdg: Many a man has been slain for me;

app.lem: Cites nomen & tounes brent.
app.rdg: Cities [have been] captured and towns [have been] burnt.

app.lem: Allas, þat ich was bore.
app.rdg: Alas, that I was ever born!

app.lem: Fader, y wil serue at wille
app.rdg: “Father, I will willingly serve

app.lem: Þe soudan boþe loude & stille,
app.rdg: The sultan, both loud and soft [no matter the conditions],

app.lem: & leue on God almiȝt.
app.rdg: And trust in the almighty God.

app.lem: Bot it so be, he schal þe spille,
app.rdg: Or else, he shall kill you,

app.lem: & alle þi lond take him tille,
app.rdg: And take all of your land for himself,

app.lem: Wiþ bateyle & wiþ fiȝt.
app.rdg: In battle and with war.

app.lem: Certes y nil no lenger dreye
app.rdg: Surely I will no longer bear

app.lem: Þat Cristen folk for me dye;
app.rdg: A Christian people to die for me;

app.lem: It were a diolful siȝt.’
app.rdg: It is so sorrowful a sight.”

app.lem: Þe king of Tars answerd þo,
app.rdg: Then the King of Tars answered,

app.lem: As man þat was in sorwe & wo,
app.rdg: A man who was in sorrow and woe,

app.lem: Vnto þat bird briȝt
app.rdg: To that lovely lady:

app.lem: ‘Now douhter, blisced mot þou be
app.rdg: “Now, daughter, may you be blessed

app.lem: Of Ihesu Crist in trinite
app.rdg: By Jesus Christ in trinity

app.lem: Þe time þat þou were bore;
app.rdg: From the hour that you were born.

app.lem: For þou wilt saue þi moder & me
app.rdg: Because you will save your mother and me,

app.lem: Al þi preier graunt y þe
app.rdg: I [will] allow everything for which you have asked,

app.lem: Astow hast seyd bifore.’
app.rdg: Just as you have said before.”

app.lem: ‘F[a]der’ sche seyd ‘wiþouten duelling,
app.rdg: “Father,” she said, “without delay,

app.lem: For Ihesus loue, heuen-king,
app.rdg: For the love of Jesus, heaven’s king,

app.lem: ȝif it þi wille wore,
app.rdg: If it were your will,

app.lem: Do now swiþe þat y war þere
app.rdg: Act now, that I will be there

app.lem: Ar ani more sorwe arere
app.rdg: Before any more sorrow arises,

app.lem: Þat ȝe be nouȝt forlore.’
app.rdg: So that you will not be hopeless.”

app.lem: Þe king of Tars, wiþ gode entent,
app.rdg: The King of Tars, with good intent,

app.lem: Hastilich after his wiif he sent,
app.rdg: Called for his wife immediately,

app.lem: Þat leuedi þat was so hende.
app.rdg: The lady who was so gentle.

app.lem: When sche was comen in present
app.rdg: When she had arrived in [his] presence

app.lem: He seyd ‘dame, our douhter haþ ment
app.rdg: He said: “Dame, our daughter has decided

app.lem: To þe soudan to wende.
app.rdg: To go over to the sultan.

app.lem: Do loke what rede is now at þe,
app.rdg: See if there is any advice you have [to give],

app.lem: For now er here bot we þre,
app.rdg: Since there are only us three

app.lem: To saue Cristen kende.’
app.rdg: To save the Christian people.”

app.lem: Þe quene answerd wiþouten feile,
app.rdg: The queen answered without mistake:

app.lem: ‘Y no schal neuer þerto conseyle
app.rdg: “No, I shall never suggest that

app.lem: Our douhter forto schende.’
app.rdg: Our daughter be put to shame.”

app.lem: Þe maiden was ful of sorwe & wo.
app.rdg: The maiden was full of sorrow and woe.

app.lem: ‘Merci’ sche crid hir moder þo
app.rdg: “Have mercy,” she cried to her mother then

app.lem: Wiþ a wel reweful steuen.
app.rdg: With such a pitiful voice.

app.lem: ‘Moder, it is nouȝt long ago
app.rdg: “Mother, it was not long ago

app.lem: For me were slawe kniȝtes þro,
app.rdg: That valiant knights were slain for me,

app.lem: Þritti þousende & seuen.
app.rdg: Thirty-thousand and seven [of them].

app.lem: Forþi y wil suffre no lenger þrawe
app.rdg: Therefore, I will no longer endure

app.lem: Þat Cristen folk be for me slawe,
app.rdg: Christian men to be slain for me,

app.lem: Wiþ þe grace of God in heuen.’
app.rdg: By the grace of God in heaven.”

app.lem: Þus þe maiden wiþ wordes stille
app.rdg: Thus, with gentle words the maiden

app.lem: Brouȝt hem boþe in better wille
app.rdg: Led them both to better understanding

app.lem: Wiþ resoun riȝt & euen.
app.rdg: By her honest and impartial judgment.

app.lem: & when þai were þus at on,
app.rdg: When they were in unison,

app.lem: Messangers þai sent anon
app.rdg: They at once sent messengers

app.lem: Vnto þat riche soudan.
app.rdg: To the wealthy sultan.

app.lem: To make his frende þat were his fon,
app.rdg: To make [themselves] his friends that were his enemies,

app.lem: & for he schuld his men nouȝt slon
app.rdg: And so [that] he should not slay his men,

app.lem: His douhter he graunt him þan.
app.rdg: [The king] then gave to him his daughter.

app.lem: Þe messangers nold no leng abide;
app.rdg: The messengers would no longer wait;

app.lem: To þe soudan þai went þat tide,
app.rdg: They went to the sultan that moment,

app.lem: & þus þai tel him gan.
app.rdg: And thus they did tell him.

app.lem: When þo letters weren yradde
app.rdg: Then when the letters were read

app.lem: Þe soudan was boþe bliþe & glad,
app.rdg: The sultan was both happy and glad,

app.lem: & so was mani a man.
app.rdg: And so were many men.

app.lem: So glad he was in al maners
app.rdg: He was so pleased in every way that

app.lem: He cleped to him of his pers,
app.rdg: He summoned from his councilors to himself

app.lem: Doukes, princes & kinges.
app.rdg: Dukes, princes, and kings.

app.lem: Into a chaumber þai went yfers
app.rdg: Together they went into a store-room

app.lem: To diȝt vnto þe messangers
app.rdg: To make ready for the messengers

app.lem: Gode stones & riche ringes.
app.rdg: Precious gems and expensive rings.

app.lem: Bi conseyl of þe lordinges alle
app.rdg: By the council of all his lords,

app.lem: Þe soudan dede bring into þe halle
app.rdg: The sultan did bring into the hall

app.lem: ȝiftes & riche þinges,
app.rdg: Gifts and lavish trinkets,

app.lem: & ȝaf to hem gret plente,
app.rdg: And gave a great abundance to them,

app.lem: To þe messangers wiþ hert fre,
app.rdg: To the messengers, out of his noble heart,

app.lem: & þonked hem her tidinges
app.rdg: And thanked them for their news.

app.lem: & seyd he was alle at his wille,
app.rdg: He said he was in full agreement,

app.lem: Arliche & late, loude & stille,
app.rdg: Whether early or late [no matter the time], loud or soft,

app.lem: To help him at his nede;
app.rdg: To help [the king] with his request;

app.lem: No more folk nold he spille.
app.rdg: He would not kill any more people.

app.lem: Þe messangers went þe king tille
app.rdg: The messengers went to the king

app.lem: & told him of þat dede.
app.rdg: And told him of that deed [the sultan’s response].

app.lem: Þe king & þe quene also
app.rdg: The king and also the queen

app.lem: Boþen hem was wele & wo,
app.rdg: Were both of them happy and sad,

app.lem: In rime also we rede.
app.rdg: In the verses which we read.

app.lem: Gret ioie þai hadde, wiþouten les,
app.rdg: They were greatly relieved, without deceit,

app.lem: For þat þe soudan wald haue pes
app.rdg: Because the sultan would have peace

app.lem: On Cristen felawerede.
app.rdg: With Christian fellowship.

app.lem: Þe first day of Iulii tide,
app.rdg: On the first day of July,

app.lem: Þe soudan nold no leng abide,
app.rdg: The sultan would no longer wait.

app.lem: To þe king of Tars he sent
app.rdg: He sent to the King of Tars

app.lem: Kniȝtes fele & michel pride
app.rdg: Many knights of great strength

app.lem: & riche iewels, is nouȝt to hide,
app.rdg: And jewels too precious to keep hidden away,

app.lem: To ȝif to his present.
app.rdg: To give [to the King] as his bride-price.

app.lem: Þe messangers, wiþouten duelling,
app.rdg: The messengers, without delay,

app.lem: Com to Tars, bifor þe king,
app.rdg: Came before the King of Tars

app.lem: To haue his douhter gent.
app.rdg: To receive his gentle daughter.

app.lem: Þai welcomed hem wiþ glad chere.
app.rdg: They welcomed him with a happy appearance.

app.lem: Of gret pite, now may ȝe here,
app.rdg: [They appeared] deeply grieved, now you may hear,

app.lem: To chaumber when þai went.
app.rdg: When they went into the bedroom.

app.lem: Þai maden cri & michel wo
app.rdg: They wept and grieved sorely

app.lem: For þai schuld her douhter forgo
app.rdg: Because they should give up their daughter

app.lem: & to þe soudan hir sende.
app.rdg: And send her to the sultan.

app.lem: Þe maiden preyd hem boþe þo
app.rdg: Then the maiden begged both of them

app.lem: Þat þai schuld bi her conseyl do
app.rdg: That they should act on her advice

app.lem: To sauen Cristen kende.
app.rdg: To save the Christian people:

app.lem: ‘For y wil suffre no lenger þrawe
app.rdg: “For I will no longer endure

app.lem: Þat Cristen folk be for me slawe.’
app.rdg: Christian people to be slain for me.”

app.lem: To halle þai gun wende,
app.rdg: They did return to the hall

app.lem: & welcomed þo messangers
app.rdg: And welcomed those messengers

app.lem: Þat com from þe soudan fers
app.rdg: That came from the wicked sultan

app.lem: Wiþ wordes fre & hende.
app.rdg: With noble and pleasing words.

app.lem: Þan seyd þe quen to hem þan
app.rdg: Then the queen said to them:

app.lem: ‘Hou fareþ ȝour lord, þe soudan,
app.rdg: “How is your lord the sultan,

app.lem: Þat is so noble a kniȝt?’
app.rdg: Who is so noble a knight?”

app.lem: Þe messangers answere gan,
app.rdg: The messengers did answer:

app.lem: ‘He farþ as wele as ani man,
app.rdg: “He is as well as any man,

app.lem: & is ȝour frende, apliȝt.’
app.rdg: And is your friend, indeed.”

app.lem: Þe quen seyd, wiþ milde chere,
app.rdg: The queen said, in a humble manner:

app.lem: ‘Wele better þei mi douhter were,
app.rdg: “He will be all the better because of my daughter,

app.lem: Bi Ihesu ful of miȝt,
app.rdg: By Jesus [who is] full of might.

app.lem: Mi douhter is nouȝt to him to gode;
app.rdg: My daughter is not too god for him,

app.lem: Y vouchesaue on him mi blode,
app.rdg: On my life, I promise him,

app.lem: Þei sche were ten so briȝt.’
app.rdg: Even if she were ten times as lovely.”

app.lem: Þe messangers diȝt hem swiþe
app.rdg: The messengers readied themselves immediately

app.lem: Wiþ kniȝtes fele & stedes stiþe
app.rdg: With many knights and hardy horses

app.lem: & brouȝt hir into chare.
app.rdg: And brought her into a chariot.

app.lem: Þe king & þe quen were vnbliþe;
app.rdg: The king and queen were so unhappy;

app.lem: Her sorwe couþe þai noman kiþe,
app.rdg: They could express their sorrow to no man

app.lem: When þai seye hir forþ fare.
app.rdg: When they saw her going away.

app.lem: [Þai seye it miȝt non oþer go;
app.rdg: [They saw that (the chariot) might not ever return;

app.lem: Bitauȝten hir God for euermo
app.rdg: They gave her up to God forevermore

app.lem: & kist her douhter þare.]
app.rdg: And kissed their daughter there].

app.lem: Into chaumber þai went þo.
app.rdg: Then they went into the bedroom.

app.lem: When þai were togider boþe to,
app.rdg: When they two were both together,

app.lem: Þan wakened alle her care.
app.rdg: Then all of their concern was loosed.

app.lem: Þe king was in sorwe bounde,
app.rdg: The king was bound by his sorrow;

app.lem: Þe quen swoned mani a stounde,
app.rdg: The queen fainted many times

app.lem: For her douhter dere.
app.rdg: For their beloved daughter.

app.lem: Kniȝtes & leuedis þer hem founde,
app.rdg: The knights and ladies found them there

app.lem: & tok hem vp hole & sounde,
app.rdg: And kept them safe and sound,

app.lem: & comfort hem in fere.
app.rdg: And comforted them with their company.

app.lem: Þus þe quen & þe king
app.rdg: Thus the queen and the king

app.lem: Liued in sorwe & care morning;
app.rdg: Lived in sorrow and concern, mourning;

app.lem: Gret diol it was to here.
app.rdg: Such a pity it was to hear!

app.lem: Her care was euer aliche newe;
app.rdg: Their concern was always renewed;

app.lem: Hem chaunged boþe hide & hewe
app.rdg: It changed their color and their appearance

app.lem: For sorwe & reweli chere.
app.rdg: Because of sorrow and guilty countenance.

app.lem: Nov late we ben alle her morning,
app.rdg: Not, let us leave behind all of their mourning,

app.lem: & telle we of þat maiden ȝing
app.rdg: And let us tell of that young maiden

app.lem: Þat to þe soudan is fare.
app.rdg: Who has gone to the sultan.

app.lem: He com wiþ mani gret lording
app.rdg: He came with many mighty lords

app.lem: For to welcome þat swete þing
app.rdg: To welcome that precious woman

app.lem: When sche was brouȝt in chare.
app.rdg: When she was brought in her chariot.

app.lem: He kist hir wel mani a siþe;
app.rdg: He kissed her many times;

app.lem: His ioie couþe he noman kiþe,
app.rdg: He could express his joy to no man.

app.lem: Oway was alle his care.
app.rdg: All his manners were forgotten.

app.lem: Into chaumber sche was ladde,
app.rdg: She was led into her bedroom,

app.lem: & richeliche sche was cladde
app.rdg: And she was ornately robed

app.lem: As heþ(þ)en wiman were.
app.rdg: Like pagan women are [veiled].

app.lem: Whan sche was cladde in riche palle,
app.rdg: When she was dressed in royal garments,

app.lem: Þe soudan dede his kniȝtes calle,
app.rdg: The sultan did summon his knights

app.lem: & badde þat maiden forþ fett.
app.rdg: And ordered them to retrieve the maiden.

app.lem: & when sche com into þe halle
app.rdg: When she came into the hall

app.lem: Bifor þe heyȝe lordinges alle,
app.rdg: Before all of the high lords,

app.lem: Toforn þe soudan þai hir sett.
app.rdg: They seated her before the sultan.

app.lem: Gret diol it was for to se
app.rdg: Such a pity it was to see

app.lem: Þe bird þat was so briȝt on ble
app.rdg: The lady who was so beautiful of complexion

app.lem: To haue so foule a mett.
app.rdg: To have so hideous a husband!

app.lem: Þei þat sche made gret solas,
app.rdg: Although she seemed to be at ease,

app.lem: Þe sorwe þat at hir hert was
app.rdg: No man could take away (396)

app.lem: No miȝt it noman lett.
app.rdg: The sorrow that was on her heart. (395)

app.lem: & whan it was comen to niȝt
app.rdg: When nighttime had fallen,

app.lem: Þe leuedi, þat was so feir & briȝt,
app.rdg: The lady who was so fair and lovely

app.lem: To chaumber sche gan wende.
app.rdg: Did retire herself to her bedroom.

app.lem: & þerin anon, y ȝou pliȝt,
app.rdg: Indeed within, I tell you truly,

app.lem: A riche bed þer was ydiȝt
app.rdg: There a lavish bed was spread

app.lem: Vnto þat leuedi hende.
app.rdg: For that pleasant lady.

app.lem: Þe leuedi was to bed ybrouȝt;
app.rdg: The lady was brought to bed;

app.lem: Þe soudan wild com þerin nouȝt,
app.rdg: The sultan would not enter into there

app.lem: Noiþer for fo no fre[n]de
app.rdg: Because he would draw near the maiden for nothing, (406)

app.lem: For noþing wold he neyȝe þat may
app.rdg: Neither as an enemy nor as a companion, (405)

app.lem: Til Þat sche leued opon his lay,
app.rdg: Until she believed in his faith,

app.lem: Þat was of Cristen kende.
app.rdg: She who was of the Christian people.

app.lem: Wel loþe war a Cristen man
app.rdg: A Christian man would be loathe

app.lem: To wedde an heþen woman
app.rdg: To marry a pagan woman

app.lem: Þat leued on fals lawe;
app.rdg: That believed in false idols;

app.lem: Als loþ was þat soudan
app.rdg: So too was the sultan loathe

app.lem: To wed a Cristen woman,
app.rdg: To marry a Christian woman,

app.lem: As y finde in mi sawe.
app.rdg: As I find in my story.

app.lem: Þe soudan ȝede to bed al prest,
app.rdg: The sultan went right away to bed;

app.lem: Kniȝtes & leuedis ȝede to rest,
app.rdg: Knights and ladies lay to rest,

app.lem: Þe pople hem gan wiþdrawe.
app.rdg: The people did excuse themselves.

app.lem: Þat miri maiden litel slepe,
app.rdg: The admirable maiden hardly slept,

app.lem: Bot al niȝt wel sore sche wepe
app.rdg: Bot al niȝt wel sore sche wepe

app.lem: Til þe day gan dawe.
app.rdg: Until the dawn of day did rise.

app.lem: & als sche fel on slepe þore
app.rdg: There as she fell to sleep

app.lem: Her þouȝt þer stode hir bifore
app.rdg: She dreamed there stood before her

app.lem: An hundred houndes blake,
app.rdg: A hundred black hounds,

app.lem: & bark on hir, lasse & more.
app.rdg: And they bayed at her unceasingly.

app.lem: & on þer was þat greued hir sore,
app.rdg: There was one which deeply troubled her,

app.lem: Oway þat wald hir take;
app.rdg: Which would snatch her away;

app.lem: & sche no durst him nouȝt smite
app.rdg: She dared not to strike him

app.lem: For drede þat he wald hir bite,
app.rdg: Out of fear that he would bite her,

app.lem: Swiche maistri he gan to make.
app.rdg: So savagely did he act.

app.lem: & as sche wald fram hem fle,
app.rdg: As she would flee from them,

app.lem: Sche seye þer stond deuelen þre,
app.rdg: She saw that three devils stood there,

app.lem: & ich brent as a drake.
app.rdg: And each smouldered like a dragon.

app.lem: So loþliche þai were al ywrouȝt
app.rdg: They were all so hideously formed,

app.lem: & ich in hond a gleiue brouȝt,
app.rdg: And each wielded a glaive in its hand,

app.lem: Sche was aferd ful sore.
app.rdg: [So] she was sorely afraid.

app.lem: On Ihesu Crist was alle hir þouȝt,
app.rdg: All of her hope was on Jesus Christ;

app.lem: Þerfore þe fendes derd hir nouȝt,
app.rdg: Therefore the fiends did not offend her,

app.lem: Noiþer lesse no more.
app.rdg: Not in any way.

app.lem: Fro þe fendes sche passed sounde,
app.rdg: She escaped safely from the fiends,

app.lem: & afterward þer com an hounde
app.rdg: And there a hound ran up behind her

app.lem: Wiþ browes brod & hore;
app.rdg: With wide, grey brows.

app.lem: Almost he hadde hir drawen adoun,
app.rdg: He had almost dragged her down,

app.lem: Ac þurth Ihesus Cristes passioun
app.rdg: But through the passion of Jesus Christ

app.lem: Sche was ysaued þore.
app.rdg: She was saved from there.

app.lem: ȝete hir þouȝt, wiþouten lesing,
app.rdg: Y et she believed, without deceit,

app.lem: Als sche lay in hir sweuening,
app.rdg: As she lay tossing and turning,

app.lem: Þat selcouþe was to rede,
app.rdg: Which is terrible to tell,

app.lem: Þat blac hounde hir was folweing
app.rdg: The black hound was following her.

app.lem: Þurth miȝt of Ihesu, heuen-king,
app.rdg: Then a knight in white clothing (451)

app.lem: Spac to hir in manhede,
app.rdg: Spoke to her in his valor (450)

app.lem: In white cloþes, als a kniȝt,
app.rdg: Through the might of Jesus, heaven’s king, (449)

app.lem: & seyd to hir ‘mi swete wiȝt,
app.rdg: And said to her: “My precious lady,

app.lem: No þarf be noþing drede,
app.rdg: There is nothing for you to be afraid of,

app.lem: Of Teruagaunt no of Mahoun.
app.rdg: [Neither] of Ternagaunt [deity ascribed to Islam] nor of Muhammad.

app.lem: Þi lord þat suffred passioun
app.rdg: Your Lord who suffered crucifixion

app.lem: Schal help þe at þi nede.’
app.rdg: Shall help you in your peril.”

app.lem: & when þe maiden was awaked,
app.rdg: When the maiden awoke [from her dream],

app.lem: For drede of þat wel sore sche quaked
app.rdg: She trembled violently out of fear

app.lem: For loue of her sweuening.
app.rdg: And dread of her nightmare.

app.lem: On hir bed sche sat al naked,
app.rdg: She sat disrobed on her bed,

app.lem: To Ihesu hir preier sche maked,
app.rdg: And she said her prayers to Jesus Christ,

app.lem: Al miȝtful heuen-king.
app.rdg: Almighty heaven’s king.

app.lem: As wis as he hir dere bouȝt
app.rdg: As surely as He had dearly redeemed her,

app.lem: Of þat sweuening, in slepe sche þouȝt,
app.rdg: [She believed] the nightmare that she dreamed in her sleep

app.lem: Schuld turn to gode ending.
app.rdg: Should close upon a happy ending.

app.lem: & when þe maiden risen was,
app.rdg: When the maiden had risen [from her bed],

app.lem: Þe riche soudan of Damas
app.rdg: The wealthy sultan of Damascus

app.lem: To his temple he gan hir bring.
app.rdg: Did bring her to his temple.

app.lem: Þan seyd þe soudan to þat may,
app.rdg: Then the sultan said to the maiden:

app.lem: ‘Þou most bileue opon mi lay
app.rdg: “You must believe in my faith

app.lem: & knele now here adoun;
app.rdg: And now kneel down here,

app.lem: & forsake þi fals lay
app.rdg: And renounce your false beliefs

app.lem: Þat þou hast leued on mani a day,
app.rdg: Which you have believed in for so long,

app.lem: & anour seyn Mahoun.
app.rdg: And worship Saint [Prophet] Muhammad.

app.lem: & certes, bot þou wilt anon,
app.rdg: Surely, unless you will do this soon,

app.lem: Þi fader y schal wiþ wer slon.
app.rdg: You father shall be slain in battle.

app.lem: Bi Iouin & Plotoun,
app.rdg: By Jove and Pluto,

app.lem: & bi Mahoun & Teruagant
app.rdg: And by Muhammad and Ternagaunt,

app.lem: Þer schal noman ben his waraunt,
app.rdg: No man shall be his protector,

app.lem: Emperour, no king wiþ croun.’
app.rdg: [Neither any] emperor, nor crowned king.”

app.lem: Þe maiden answerd wiþ mild chere
app.rdg: In a humble manner, the maiden answered

app.lem: To þe soudan, as ȝe may here,
app.rdg: To the sultan, as you may hear:

app.lem: ‘Sir, y nil þe nouȝt greue.
app.rdg: “Sire, I will do nothing to offend you.

app.lem: Teche me now & lat me here
app.rdg: Teach me now, and let me hear

app.lem: Hou y schal make mi preiere
app.rdg: How I should say my prayer

app.lem: When ich on hem bileue.
app.rdg: When I believe in them.

app.lem: To Mahoun ichil me take,
app.rdg: I will devote myself to Muhammad

app.lem: & Ihesu Crist, mi Lord, forsake,
app.rdg: And give up my Lord Jesus Christ

app.lem: Þat made Adam & Eue.
app.rdg: Who made Adam and Eve.

app.lem: & seþþen serue þe at wille,
app.rdg: Thereafter will I serve you in all things,

app.lem: Arliche & lat, loude & stille,
app.rdg: [Whether] early or late, loud or soft,

app.lem: Amorwe & an eue.’
app.rdg: In the morning and at dusk.”

app.lem: Þan was þe soudan glad & bliþe,
app.rdg: Then the sultan was glad and happy,

app.lem: & þanked Mahoun mani siþe
app.rdg: And thanked Muhammad over and over

app.lem: Þat sche was so biknawe;
app.rdg: Since she was converted;

app.lem: His ioie couþe he noman kiþe.
app.rdg: To nobody could he express his joy

app.lem: He bad hir gon & kis swiþe
app.rdg: He ordered her to go and kiss at once

app.lem: ‘Alle þine godes on rawe.’
app.rdg: “All of your gods, one after the other.”

app.lem: Sche kist Mahoun & Apolin,
app.rdg: She kissed Muhammad and Apollyon,

app.lem: Astirot, & sir Iouin,
app.rdg: Ishtar, and Lord Jove

app.lem: Ishtar, and Lord Jove
app.rdg: Out of fear of his terrible threats.

app.lem: & while sche was in þe temple [þer]
app.rdg: While she stayed [there] in the temple

app.lem: Of Teruagant & Iubiter
app.rdg: Of Ternagaunt and Jupiter,

app.lem: Sche lerd þe heþen lawe.
app.rdg: She learned the heathen faith.

app.lem: & þei sche al þe lawes couþe,
app.rdg: Although she understood all of the tenets

app.lem: & seyd hem openliche wiþ hir mouþe,
app.rdg: And professed them outwardly with her mouth,

app.lem: Ihesu forȝat sche nouȝt.
app.rdg: She had not forgotten Jesus.

app.lem: Wher þat sche was, bi norþe or souþe,
app.rdg: Wherever she was, be it north or south [no matter the location],

app.lem: No minstral wiþ harp no crouþe
app.rdg: No performer playing the harp or lyre

app.lem: No miȝt chaunge hir þouȝt.
app.rdg: Could ever change her conviction.

app.lem: Þe soudan wende niȝt & day
app.rdg: Night and day, the sultan was convinced

app.lem: Þat sche hadde leued opon his lay,
app.rdg: That she had believed in his faith,

app.lem: Bot al he was bicouȝt.
app.rdg: But he was none the wiser,

app.lem: For when sche was bi hirselue on
app.rdg: Because when she was alone by herself,

app.lem: To Ihesu sche made hir mon,
app.rdg: She said her prayer to Jesus

app.lem: Þat alle þis world haþ wrouȝt.
app.rdg: Who has created the entire world.

app.lem: Þe soudan dede cri þat tide
app.rdg: At that time, the sultan did announce

app.lem: Oueral, bi ich aside,
app.rdg: To every corner of his kingdom

app.lem: A turnament to take;
app.rdg: To hold a tournament;

app.lem: & duhti men on hors to ride,
app.rdg: The mighty men [rode] out on their horses,

app.lem: & dubbed hem in þat tide,
app.rdg: And he enfeoffed them at that time,

app.lem: & kniȝtes gan he make.
app.rdg: And did make them knights.

app.lem: Be trumpes gun forto blowe;
app.rdg: The trumpets sounded forth;

app.lem: Kniȝtes priked out o rouwe
app.rdg: Knights spurred out of line

app.lem: On stedes white & blake.
app.rdg: On white and black horses.

app.lem: Þer miȝt men se sone & swiþe
app.rdg: Men could watch then and there

app.lem: Strong men her strengþe kiþe
app.rdg: Strong men show off their strength

app.lem: For þat maiden sake.
app.rdg: For the maiden’s sake.

app.lem: Þe Cristen maiden & þe soudan
app.rdg: The Christian maiden and the sultan

app.lem: In þe castel leyen þan,
app.rdg: Remained within the castle

app.lem: Þe turnament to bihold.
app.rdg: To view the tournament.

app.lem: & þo þe turnament bigan
app.rdg: When the tournament had begun,

app.lem: Þer was samned mani a man
app.rdg: There were gathered many men

app.lem: Of Sarraȝins stout & bold.
app.rdg: Of Muslims strong and bold.

app.lem: To sen þer was a semly siȝt,
app.rdg: To watch there was a wonderful sight

app.lem: Of þritti þousend of helmes briȝt,
app.rdg: Of thirty-thousand shining helmets,

app.lem: In gest as it is told.
app.rdg: As it is told in the legend.

app.lem: Þai leyden on as þai were wroþe
app.rdg: They struggled as if they were mad

app.lem: Wiþ swerdes & wiþ maces boþe,
app.rdg: With both swords and with maces,

app.lem: Kniȝtes boþe ȝong & old.
app.rdg: Knights both young and old.

app.lem: Wel mani helme þer was ofweued,
app.rdg: So many helmets were struck off,

app.lem: & mani bacinet tocleued,
app.rdg: Many visors [were] split in half,

app.lem: & kniȝtes driuen to grounde.
app.rdg: And knights [were] driven to the ground.

app.lem: Sum þer fel doun on her heued,
app.rdg: There some fell down on their heads,

app.lem: & sum in þe diche lay todreued,
app.rdg: And some lay fallen in the ditch,

app.lem: & siked sore vnsounde.
app.rdg: And cried out, badly wounded.

app.lem: Þe turnament last þo, y pliȝt,
app.rdg: Indeed, the tournament lasted this long,

app.lem: Fram þe morwe to þe niȝt,
app.rdg: From dawn to dusk,

app.lem: Of men of michel mounde.
app.rdg: Of men of abounding power.

app.lem: Amorwe þe soudan wedded þat may
app.rdg: The next morning, the sultan married the maiden

app.lem: In þe maner of his lay,
app.rdg: In keeping the customs of his faith,

app.lem: In gest as it is founde.
app.rdg: As it is found in the legend.

app.lem: Atte his bridale was noble fest,
app.rdg: At the reception was a noble feast,

app.lem: Riche, real, & onest;
app.rdg: Sumptuous, fit for a king, and formal;

app.lem: Doukes [&] kinges wiþ croun.
app.rdg: [There were] dukes [and] crowned kings.

app.lem: For þer was melodi wiþ þe mest
app.rdg: There was the finest song

app.lem: Of harp & fiþel & of gest
app.rdg: Of harps and fiddles, and legends sung

app.lem: To lordinges of renoun.
app.rdg: Of celebrated heroes.

app.lem: Þer was ȝeuen to þe menstrels
app.rdg: There were given to the performers

app.lem: Robes riche & mani iuweles
app.rdg: Royal robes and many precious gems

app.lem: Of erl & of baroun.
app.rdg: [Befitting] of earls and barons.

app.lem: Þe fest lasted fourteniȝt,
app.rdg: The feast lasted fourteen days,

app.lem: Wiþ mete & drink anouȝ, apliȝt,
app.rdg: With enough of meat and drink, indeed,

app.lem: Plente & gret fousoun.
app.rdg: Plentiful and great in store.

app.lem: Þat leuedi, so feir & so fre,
app.rdg: The lady so lovely and so noble

app.lem: Was wiþ hir lord bot moneþes þre
app.rdg: Was with her husband for but three months

app.lem: Þan he gat hir wiþ childe.
app.rdg: Before he had made her pregnant.

app.lem: When it was geten sche chaunged ble;
app.rdg: When she became pregnant, she changed in appearance.

app.lem: Þe soudan himself þat gan se,
app.rdg: The sultan himself did see it;

app.lem: Iolif he was & wilde.
app.rdg: He was joyous and exciteful.

app.lem: Þerwhile sche was wiþ child, apliȝt,
app.rdg: Indeed, while she was pregnant,

app.lem: Sche bad to Ihesu ful of miȝt
app.rdg: She begged of Jesus, full of might,

app.lem: Fram schame he schuld hir schilde.
app.rdg: [That] he should defend her from shame.

app.lem: Atte fourti woukes ende
app.rdg: At the end of forty weeks

app.lem: Þe leuedi was deliuerd o[f] bende
app.rdg: The lady was brought out of labor

app.lem: Þurth help of Mari milde.
app.rdg: Through the help of mild Mary.

app.lem: & when þe child was ybore
app.rdg: When the child was born,

app.lem: Wel sori wimen were þerfore,
app.rdg: The women were appalled thereby

app.lem: For lim no hadde it non.
app.rdg: Because [the baby] had no limbs.

app.lem: Bot as a rond of flesche yschore
app.rdg: But like a lump of butchered flesh

app.lem: In chaumber it lay hem bifore
app.rdg: It lay before them in the bedroom,

app.lem: Wiþouten blod & bon.
app.rdg: Lacking blood and bones.

app.lem: For sorwe þe leuedi wald dye
app.rdg: The lady wished to die of grief

app.lem: For it hadde noiþer nose no eye,
app.rdg: Because it had not either a nose or eyes,

app.lem: Bot lay ded as þe ston.
app.rdg: But lay as dead as a stone.

app.lem: Þe soudan com to chaumber þat tide,
app.rdg: The sultan entered the bedroom at that moment

app.lem: & wiþ his wiif he gan to chide
app.rdg: And began to blame his wife

app.lem: Þat wo was hir bigon.
app.rdg: For the trouble that had come of her:

app.lem: ‘O Dame’ he seyd biforn,
app.rdg: “Oh dame,” he said before her,

app.lem: ‘Oȝain mi godes þou art forsworn,
app.rdg: “You are cursed by my gods,

app.lem: Wiþ riȝt resoun y preue:
app.rdg: I prove with sound judgement:

app.lem: Þe childe þat is here of þe born
app.rdg: The child which is born of you here

app.lem: Boþe lim & liþ it is forlorn
app.rdg: Is deprived of both life and limb

app.lem: Alle þurth þi fals bileue.
app.rdg: All because of your false belief.

app.lem: Þou leuest nouȝt wele afine
app.rdg: You do not believe truly

app.lem: On Iubiter no on Apoline
app.rdg: On Jupiter or on Apollyon,

app.lem: Amorwe na an eue;
app.rdg: [And pray] neither in the morning nor in the evening,

app.lem: No in Mahoun no in Teruagant,
app.rdg: Not on Muhammad nor on Ternagaunt.

app.lem: Þerfore is lorn þis litel faunt,
app.rdg: That is why this little child is hopeless,

app.lem: No wonder þei me greue.’
app.rdg: No wonder the gods disturb me!”

app.lem: Þe leuedi answerd & seyd þo,
app.rdg: Then the lady answered and said,

app.lem: Þer sche lay in care & wo,
app.rdg: There where she lay in concern and woe:

app.lem: ‘Leue sir, lat be þat þouȝt.
app.rdg: “Dear sire, let be that thought;

app.lem: Þe child was ȝeten bitven ous to;
app.rdg: The child was gotten between us both.

app.lem: For þi bileue it farþ so
app.rdg: Because you believe this so happens

app.lem: Bi him þat ous haþ wrouȝt.
app.rdg: By He who has created us,

app.lem: Take now þis flesche, & bere it anon
app.rdg: Take this flesh, and bring it at once

app.lem: Bifor þine godes euerichon,
app.rdg: Before every one of your gods,

app.lem: Þat þou no lete it nouȝt.
app.rdg: So that you spare it nothing.

app.lem: & pray þine godes al yfere,
app.rdg: Pray to all of your gods together,

app.lem: Astow art hem leue & dere,
app.rdg: As you are loved and dear to them,

app.lem: To liue þat it be brouȝt.
app.rdg: That it be brought to life.

app.lem: & if Mahoun & Iouin can
app.rdg: “If Muhammad and Jove can

app.lem: Make it fourmed after a man
app.rdg: Have it fashioned like a man

app.lem: Wiþ liif & limes ariȝt,
app.rdg: With life and healthy limbs,

app.lem: Bi Ihesu Crist, þat þis warld wan,
app.rdg: By Jesus Christ who has redeemed this world,

app.lem: Y schal leue þe better þan
app.rdg: I shall love you better than

app.lem: Þat þai ar ful of miȝt.
app.rdg: They do, who are full of might.

app.lem: & bot þai it to liue bring
app.rdg: Unless they bring it to life,

app.lem: Y nil leuen on hem noþing
app.rdg: For nothing will I rely on them,

app.lem: Noiþer bi day no niȝt.’
app.rdg: Neither by day nor by night.”

app.lem: Þe soudan toke þat flesche anon;
app.rdg: The sultan took the flesh at once;

app.lem: Into his temple he gan to gon
app.rdg: He did enter into his temple

app.lem: Þer his godes were diȝt.
app.rdg: Where his gods were installed.

app.lem: Biforn his goddes he gan it leyn,
app.rdg: He offered it up before his gods,

app.lem: & held vp his honden tvein
app.rdg: And held up both of his hands

app.lem: While men miȝt go fiue mile.
app.rdg: For as much time as a man could walk five miles.

app.lem: ‘A miȝtful Mahoun’ he gan to seyn,
app.rdg: “Ah, mighty Muhammad,” he began to say,

app.lem: ‘& Teruagaunt of michel meyn,
app.rdg: “And Ternagaunt of so much power,

app.lem: In ȝou was neuer no gile.
app.rdg: There was never deceit among you.

app.lem: Seyn Iubiter & Apolin,
app.rdg: Saint Jupiter and Apollyon,

app.lem: Astirot & seyn Iouin,
app.rdg: Ishtar and Lord Jove,

app.lem: Help now in þis perile.’
app.rdg: Help me now in this peril.”

app.lem: Oft he kneled & oft he ros,
app.rdg: Often he kneeled and often he stood,

app.lem: & crid so long til he was hos;
app.rdg: And shouted so long that he lost his voice,

app.lem: & al he tint his while.
app.rdg: [But] all of his effort he wasted.

app.lem: & when he hadde al ypreyd,
app.rdg: When he had finished praying

app.lem: & alle þat euer he couþe he seyd,
app.rdg: All that he had ever learned to say,

app.lem: Þe flesche lay stille as ston.
app.rdg: The flesh lay as still as a stone.

app.lem: Anon he stirt vp at a breyd,
app.rdg: Suddenly, he stood upright,

app.lem: & in his hert he was atreyd
app.rdg: And in his heart he was torn

app.lem: For lim no hadde it non.
app.rdg: Because it [still] had no limbs.

app.lem: He biheld on his godes alle
app.rdg: He looked on each of his gods

app.lem: & seye þer miȝt no bot bifalle;
app.rdg: And saw that there was no help to come;

app.lem: Wel wo was him bigon.
app.rdg: He became despondent.

app.lem: ‘O sir Mahoun’ he gan to grede,
app.rdg: “Oh sire Muhammad,” he began to groan,

app.lem: ‘Wil ȝe nouȝt helpe me at þis nede?
app.rdg: “Will you not help me in this peril?

app.lem: Þe deuel ȝou brenne ichon.’
app.rdg: Let the devil burn each one of you!”

app.lem: He hent a staf wiþ grete hete,
app.rdg: With profound hatred he raised a staff

app.lem: & stirt anon his godes to bete,
app.rdg: And started at once to beat his gods,

app.lem: & drouȝ hem alle adoun.
app.rdg: And drove them all down.

app.lem: & leyd on til he gan to swete,
app.rdg: He lashed until he began to sweat,

app.lem: & ȝaf hem strokes gode & gret
app.rdg: And gave them beatings hard and heavy

app.lem: Boþe Iouine & Plotoun.
app.rdg: Both Jove and Pluto.

app.lem: & alderbest he bete afin
app.rdg: Even harder did he pummel

app.lem: Iubiter & Apolin,
app.rdg: Jupiter and Apollyon,

app.lem: & brac hem arm & croun.
app.rdg: And broke their arms and crowns.

app.lem: & Teruagaunt, þat was her broþer,
app.rdg: On Ternagaunt which was their brother,

app.lem: He no lete neuer a lime wiþ oþer,
app.rdg: He left not a limb with its opposite,

app.lem: No of his god Mahoun.
app.rdg: Neither on his god Muhammad.

app.lem: & when he hadde beten hem gode won,
app.rdg: When he had thoroughly beaten each one of them,

app.lem: ȝete lay þe flesche stille so ston
app.rdg: The flesh lay still as a stone

app.lem: An heye on his auter.
app.rdg: And high upon his altar.

app.lem: He tok it in his hond anon,
app.rdg: He took it in his hands at once;
